<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_chmod:
```c
int32 OS_chmod(const char *path, uint32 access_mode)
{
    char  local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN];
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_TranslatePath(path, local_path);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_FileChmod_Impl(local_path, access_mode);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_chmod:
#define OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN (OS_MAX_PATH_LEN+OS_FS_PHYS_NAME_LEN)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_FileChmod_Impl(local_path, access_mode);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated in the shown fragment. The function only passes a pointer to a local buffer (local_path) to OS_FileChmod_Impl after OS_TranslatePath returned success; there are no string.h calls here. A violation could occur only if (1) OS_TranslatePath did not ensure the path is null-terminated and within OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN or (2) OS_FileChmod_Impl uses a string.h routine (e.g. strcpy/strcat/memcpy) that writes beyond the bounds of the object referred to by local_path. Those conditions are not visible in the fragment, so based on the provided code the rule is not violated.
